content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												State of decay is one of the best third person survival horror open world game. Graphics is good enough, story is fine. SoD is not a brainless zombie killing game, you are a member of a community stucked in Thumbull county. Player have to manage the community which includes doing favoures for survivors to gain trust to become friends later; scavenging for vital supplies such as food, medicine, building materials. In the game you have a "home base" which can be upgraded with 9 facilities, and also has  space for outpost to build. Outposts extends the safe area and have supply cache to restock your equipment. The game can be played id different ways, someone likes playing stealthy, others prefer brute force to complete missions. Ah, the missions; i found side missions a bit repetitive, but they are okay. Driving cars is useful but makes a lot of noise which attracts zombies. When you are at your base you can change the character you are playing if the other character is your friend. Changing is adviseable to let the used character rest to get their vitality and stamina back to maximum value. SoD is beyond my expectations, i recommended everyone who loves zombie games 9/10.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
 In my opinion, one the difinitive zombie survival games. I'd take this over DayZ anyday!State of Decay is basically at its core is a single player, third person 'Zombie Survival' action game, with sim like management elements. When you start off you're in control of one guy who, with his chum, gets lost while hiking. If, by some miracle you dont die, you'll never see the more interesting mechanics of 'State of Decay', which is that when you die, you take control of a different character instead. You dont respawn. This makes choices matter a whole lot more than in most games, as you always have something to lose when going out to get supplies with a band of survivers.You also have to manage the survivers health, morale, supplies (and inherantly, the shortages that will occur) and generally look after them. Characters will get tired over time, and you'll have to swap out the playable character for a bit while they regain thier energy. This brings me to one of the games more annoying mechanics. Even when you're not there, the game world is still moving, albiet at a slower pace. Survivors can die, run away, starve, and generally things can go bad fast when you arn't there. While it's a cool idea, I found it just became annoying to patch up the band of survivors, turn off the game, only to find that someone had been killed off when I came back. Gameplay:Controls are reasonably responsive. Sometime it feels a little sluggish and the jumping mechanics are a little floaty, but it's all servisable, and doesn't impact the game a whole lot. You have the options of melee weapons, or guns when dealing with the undead. Combat is passable; nothing more. You'll find yourself spamming the attack button as your character losing stamina while the zombie you're wailing on continues to suck the durability from your weapon. The game really punishes you (which I love!) for trying to take on large groups of Zombies, as you'll find you'll be quickly overwelmed. Guns are also an option, but are loud, crude and are in limited supply. Usually a last resort unless you have a silencer. In conclusion: One of the better surval sim games out there.

YouTube™ Video: State of Decay: Gameplay First Look 

			Views: 363		

			First Look State of Decay video showcasing PC Gameplay. State of Decay reviews, impressions, tips and features to get you started. Thank you for watching, like, comment and subscribe if you enjoyed!		

Is it another zombie game? Well yes. But that doesn't mean it's more of the same. I think State of Decay tries to do what games like DayZ cannot which is a survival zombie experience without the threat of being killed by a real player.It's not as agressive as DayZ in terms of surviving but the fact that you have to explore, scavenge and find ways of progressing makes it very compelling. You also take part as the guy in charge so whatever happens is on your own hands.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												State of Decay is one of the best zombie games in recent memory. However, I wouldn't call it perfection. In fact, this game has plenty of flaws.In the graphics section, I found it to be pretty nice for the most part. However, in the beginning of the game, the lighting is absolutely terrible and hurt my eyes a bit. Despite that, the visuals were extremely nice and I was itching to take a few nice screenshots. However, I can't call it the #1 best part. It's still very well done.The gameplay is heated, difficult, and in some ways, realistic. The gameplay is probably the best part to the game. When you think of zombie games, I assume that you would imagine some dude with a six-pack running around shirtless with shades on dual wielding sub-machine guns, right? State of Decay is NOT like that. These are just human beings we're talking about, not supersoldiers. In fact, if there's anyone people would consider cheap in this game, it would be the Army. But hey, we're talking about the Army here. Did you really think a soldier would be running around and getting tired quick and having a miserable aim? Anyway, running away from hordes IS NOT a good idea. I've tried to run several times, but I've only gotten out alive once or twice. The people who did survive had severe injuries, were extremely tired, or have no useful items left on them. The vehicles are simple enough to drive, and making them limited just makes the game even harder. Very good gameplay.The story is cliche, no doubt. Survivors are holed up in a certian place (In State of Decay, Trumbull County) and the Army refuses to help. However, it seems rather difficult to actually come up with a decent plot for a zombie survival game without realizing someone else did that already. The audio is above average at most. The voice acting is fine, at times weak. It sometimes sounds sarcastic or the mic is far away. However, some of the actors do provide some emotion. The music is great for a zombie survival game, and I usually rely on the music to tell me if the zeds are nearby. Although again, the music is a bit cliche since several zombie survival games (and even shows) use guitars or things like that for their soundtrack. But, the soundtrack is very good in this game and is better than lots of other games and shows that use the soundtrack like this.The replayability is very strong in this game. If you beat the game, you can play through it again once or twice. There's also the two DLC packs that were very critically acclaimed you can buy, too. I didn't get either one yet, but Breakdown looks extremely fun. It's actually number one on my wishlist right now.State of Decay does have a few other major flaws I'd like to point out: The AI in this game is absolutely HORRIBLE. One of my survivors stood there doing ABSOLUTELY nothing while getting eaten by a horde of zombies. Since my guy was tired, I had to run the zombies over. And because usually the survivors dodge the car, he just stood there, doing absolutely nothing. When I hit him, he stood there and I lost trust with him. It was even one of the trust missions where someone is feeling angry, sad, or whatever. He also took like half an hour to get all of his things while the houses next to him were infested when we rescued him. Still though, BAD AI. The dialogue is repetitive and there's not many stories when you're bringing survivors back home. That's probably about it in terms of major flaws.In the end, State of Decay is quite fun and there's lots to do, but the game has some very major flaws that can ruin your experience. Either way, this is a game I'd recommend for any zombie survival fan.Graphics- 8.0/10Gameplay- 9.0/10Story- 4.0/10Audio- 7.5/10Replayability- 9.0/10.:7.5/10:.+Great gameplay+Large world+Awesome soundtrack+Impressive job by some of the voice actors-Awful AI-Repetitive dialogue-Weak lighting early game

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
												I dreaded to play this game. I was watching the alpha/beta development of this game for a little while, and while I liked a lot of what I read about it, looking at the content didn't look 'refined' enough.The gameplay is not anywhere as smooth as I had hoped and it's hard for me to get past the pre-rendered animations for literally every action. In the beginning I was watching my npc friend attack a zombie and you could see when each attack animation would create a 'stutter' between the next attack.Right in the beginning I watched a zombie trap it self climbing up a ledge, clipping back down, then repeating over and over again.The controls as a whole feel awkward to command and execute, with a lot of fine mouse sensitivity just to execute bulky, long animation sequences.The camera doesn't zoom out very far at all either. For an open world zombie game, your field of view  feels kind of narrow and your character takes up a good size on the screen.The gameplay is nothing like Left 4 Dead, but more like a more arcade gamestyle of Dead Rising with  a Dead Island feel.You do get vehicles in this game though, and they handle really nice. They drive with a good weight to them, rather than the sometimes glidy feel of running around in the game.My biggest gripe about the game is all the heavily scripted actions, which doesn't work when the combat generally tends to be just button mashing, making your character attack at nothing a few times to catch up with all the times you mashed the attack button.I don't know how much can be improved upon with patches and this first game is rather bumpy in a lot of ways and would only recommend to buy on sale, I could definitely see this turning into a worthwhile series. The gameplay is unique and interesting enough that it can definitely be worth expanding on.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
 State of Decay I am going to review the Base > Game  + the DLC later on, but i wanted to focus on SoD right now. There is a lot of Hate towards Undead Labs, over SoD being released way to early during Alpha, and it still being broken and or not finished! But they continue to apply Updates to the Base > Game  making it better each time. There are still a few bugs but I'm sure they will be addressed in the near future.I know there is still a lot of people not being able to play it because... Lets face it it's Poorly Optimized. Even a High End Rig can struggle playing it, but it's a Port from 360 and this may change in the future. I also experience a little lag from time to time, but it's not game breaking in any way for me. Usually when i enter Marshal it does it for a few seconds, then goes back to normal. For me it was an over all fun experience. I enjoyed it the first play though, but it does has those bugs that.  Well just ruin the atmosphere of the whole Survival experience, when a zombie falls through the floor during a mission and you cannot progress without killing it... (But you cannot hit it underneath the dang house) can be frustrating and take the fun out of it.There are Elements i wish they would have added or Left in as other people described from there experience on the 360 version. Like (Generators) i really liked that idea, and being able to (Load up your Truck) with Ruck Sacks when you find more than one. But don't base your judgment on (Should i Buy this? or Not?), merely based on haters in the forums, you should always form your own opinion while playing it your self. I love Horror/Zombie games, i gave it shot and I'm still here playing it :) (Love the DLC More) and I'm still unlocking Hidden Characters!Plus there are frequent Sales on the Store and you can pick up a copy pretty cheap, so really you have nothing to lose it  is worth the Price, some may disagree but to each his own. It has it's flaws and it also has it appeals, below is a list of my Pro's & Con's for State of Decay.Pro's of SoD:---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------1 - Open world you can explore freely, at times. (Some Area's Require Story Progress) to access them.2 - Drive any vehicle you want, and run down Hoards of Undeads! (You know you want to)3 - Change your Home > Base (Several Potential Home Bases) to choose from all over the map.  4 - Build up your Base, to help you and your fellow Survivors... Well Survive lol.  Medical Tent, Sleeping Quarters, Garden, Work Shop, Sniper Post, Library. - I forgot a couple.  5 - Build Outposts, to better defend your Home > Base from random Hordes, and Zombie Spawns.  The number of Out Posts, is based on how large the Home Base is. It can be anywhere from 4 to 9.  6 - Interact with any Person (NPC) you meet, some are Neighbors. And some are just trying to Survive!  And some are just♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥Bags... Yes i am referring to the Wilkersons... When they killed Becca i wanted  to drive to there farm house and burn it to the freaking ground!!  7 - Enter/Loot any Building you may encounter, it's a large map so there is loads of places to Rob Blind :)  8 - Befriend Survivors, and have them watch your back while your out in the world Scavenging.  9 - Take part in Random Events that pop up, like Zed Hunting, or Besieged- odd name?  And gain trust with them, eventually they will join you.Con's of SoD:---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------1 - Lilly Ritter... She can become quite annoying. While our immersing your self in the world of the dead, she will keep asking you to go here, go there, and just keep bugging you in general :( 2 - Vehicle Physics, are still not the best. They are still Floaty at times, and the smallest thing like a "tiny Rock" can flip over your 4X4 truck going 25 MPH. Even after a few Updates Tweaking this feature. /Facepalm. 3 - The Story is spotty and not really well done, at times if can leave you feeling lost and not sure what to next. And you can spend a lot of time just thinking WTF standing around... When it suddenly pops up telling you your next Objective to Progress the story... 4 - The Survivors AI is really poorly done, you can spend a lot of time back tracking trying to get Him/Her unstuck from behind a gate they could have just opened /Facepalm. That and they often just stand around your home base not doing anything but eating up Resources. They will get (Stuck/Lost) a lot making it harder. 5 - Looting a Building/Home, you will often find (Items/Weapons) you need but do don't have space for. So you will leave it in there and head back to base Unload and get side tracked. If you save Quit or Crash and load it back up they will be all gone, empty stash in the places you Scavenged... 6 - Optimization Issues, the game still needs Tweaking and Feature Updates. Hell it took forever before they finally allowed us to Pre-Define our damn Controls! But the Options/Settings are still lacking and will need to be addressed.7 - Boarding up windows... Ok i love the feature of being able to fortify my Base or Random House by Boarding up the windows keeping the Dead outside, but it was poorly implemented. It vanishes if you travel to far away from the place you boarded up, and when you Quit and load back up it was all for not... Now i can see losing some to Zeds trying to break in while I'm away but really? Just randomly disappears not cool.But that's always subject to change, like i said before they will be doing Updates to the Base > Game  and it can improve over time, but i like the game. Once i bought the DLC (Break Down) i just loved it because it removed the Story allowing me to really immers myself into the experince, i will do a review on BD next.I hope this helped some people, we all have different experinces when playing but overall it was a good game.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												This is the game I have been looking for since the Zombie Hype following "DayZ". It combines a Survival Game with fun fights (nothing beats fighting zombies with wrestling moves), several home bases, which can be upgraded and customized for your way of playing and rudimentary role-playing elements. And it is all completely Single Player. For some this might be a reason not to buy, but for this player it was the argument that sold the game. The game has a permadeath system and adapted it perfectly for a SP game. The player does not start with "his own" character. You rather start the story join a group of survivor, all playable for the character. All the characters in the game get exhausted and get debuffs through this. The player than has to return to the home base and choose another survivor to continue. This system is extremely fun as you can develop several different characters and ways of playing the game within one playthrough.Another mechanic which makes this game great is the resource management. The survivors don't spend all day with slaying zombies and driving around town. Most of the time cabinets, crates and all kinds of storage stuff is searched and looted. The player has to do this as the home base needs four resources. Food, to keep everyone well fed; Ammo, with a lot ammo in stock the home base has a decent supply of ammo for every firearm; Materials, to build and upgrade the home base and outposts, and medicine, this act the same way as ammo does a lot of supply equals lots of drugs at the home base. The most fun part of the game is the fighting. The player can either fight with blunt, sharp or heavy melee weapons or several firearms. The range of melee weapons goes from table legs to sledgehammers to cavalry sabres. Melee combat is mostly used in the game as guns are loud and the zombies react to sounds. This review just touches the surface of the game but I really hope that it helped you in any way. With best regards Invisiblo

content:
Posted: April 19, 2015
 Note: I deleted my initial popular review (March 30, 2014), in order re-write it and make sure the EDITED one (this one) re-appears again in the review section page.  Original Review (Short Version)  If you are obsessed with open-world zombie survival horror games, 'State of Decay' will give you an erection.  New Review based on the fiasco with the Year-One Edition I've become sick with the gaming industry, and this is perhaps one of the games that I'd never expect would go 'stealing' mode for a couple of extra bucks from people who ALREADY own their game.With their new edition of the game, they've added a 1080p quality with an extra car  (no fix for the ridiculous car physics though)  and an air-drop mission that sounds like a simple  grab-and-return-the supplies-home  feature and ask for customers who already own the original game and both DLC's to pay an extra 20 euro (with the -33% discount included) for this 'upgrade'. An 'upgrade' that  SHOULD BE FREE for owners  of the game, as is the case with all games out there (and especially the Indie titles). THIS IS A PATCH at best. It should be a PATCH. NOT A FREAKIN' FULL PRICE RE-RELEASE OF THE GAME.Moreover, the endless bugs of the original game were left unfixed, to be partly fixed in this new version, completely abandoning the ORIGINAL version... Funny enough, new bugs emerged so although some were fixed, the game STILL remains as buggy as it was, if not even more... Microsoft Studios  and  Undead Labs  are literally asking customers: "You want some of  the bugs we abandoned fixing in the original game fixed? Pay 20 euro for them!"My answer to that is clear:  'NO'. I've paid around 30 euro for the base game along with the two DLCs. I am not paying an extra 20 euro for a 'remake'. And an  unecessary remake, to be precise, since the game was released no more than 1,5 years ago. Certainly, I'd understand such a visual upgrade if the game was a 2000's title, but doing so for a game released in 2013 is preposterous - clearly a quick cash-grab from the owners of the original game if you ask me. Why  Microsoft Studios ? Why?To me, unless owners of the game with BOTH DLC's have AT LEAST a -70% discount for this minor upgrade of the game, there is no way I am recommending this, and I'd advise you withhold purchasing  (especially if you already own the game)  because by supporting such moves from developers will only make things worst for  us  gamers... Just imagine every title, every game out there, after one year of the initial release, coming up with a hypothetical 'remastered' version of the game with slightly better visual quality and an extra 'car' or 'mission' that should be there in the first place and asking for almost the full price of the game AGAIN, from people who ALREADY own the full game. And above all, you are FORCED to buy it since the company no longer cares about the original (older) version, but rather "focuses" on the new one. Trust me, that would be a disaster... People are upset and this shows from the huge drop on the game's ratings (from 94% positive to 89% positive in two days), and the numbers keep dropping... Honestly, it pains me, because I used to like State of Decay. Unfortunately it's yet another game that fell in the pitfall of 'greed'.EDIT: As it turns out, YOSE is out and it is a complete disaster. People claim that they can barely tell the visual quality difference between the "new" and the "old" version and the new 'additions' are MODS at best and some of them already exist on the NEXUS!! I do NOT recommend it any longer

number of helpful: 13 of 23 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												Let me just say this. I really wanted to enjoy this game. But after hours of playing it, I just can't.When it was announced, I was really hyped up and wanted to play it so bad. But once it got released and then I played it for hours, I was filled with nothing but boredom and disappointment.I'll start with the positives since good reviewers should always start with the good and then the bad. There's a lot of fun to be had here. The intense feeling of being chased by zombie hordes, finding supplies to keep yourself alive and fighting zombies. All whilst leveling yourself up so you can take on the hardest of things.Not only that, but there's quests that you get to do as well and some of these quests can repeat themselves too. So you're never short on never having anything to do except just running around.Unfortunately, here's where the bad comes in.The game plays like I'm playing a game on Facebook. If you had a stash of 35 food and then you quit the game to go do something else. Guess what? Once you come back to the game, you find out that your stash of food is only 10 and you'll have to spend all your hard work to go get some more. It ticks me off just to see a game that can play all by itself and then I come back to it, only to find that I'm doing worse than before once I come back on to play it. So it's either play this game after you get done with anything else or just stop playing it forever. Hey Undead Labs. This is Steam. Not freaking Facebook.Also, this is just personal opinion, but I hate the special infected in this. I encountered a big muscular zombie and then once I got too close to him, he grabbed my survivor with his huge hand and ripped him in two. This is an instant kill as well and it doesn't matter if you have full or near full health. I wouldn't have a problem with this if they would only appear AFTER I got a bunch of stuff and survivors. But they seem to appear too early in the game and it's just flat out unfair to the player in my eyes.This game can be unfair at times as well. For example, you'll be in a house with someone and you're trying to fight a few zombies that are attacking you. You are doing so great and you managed to beat them all. But then another zombie comes in and you're already out of stamina like you got freaking asthma. Hence, you can't fight as well if you don't have the stamina in order to swing a weapon. But the stamina drains like you're swinging a freaking sledgehammer when you're not even using one and it regenerates so slow as well if you don't level it up early in the game. The difficulty in this game can either be flat out frustratingly annoying or just total cheapness. Even so, they even promised and announced multiplayer on certain websites on this game too. But boy we're we disappointed when this game got released. This is another big issue to me. I hate developers who don't bring something they promise to their games. Undead Labs, if you needed more time to implement multiplayer into your games, I wouldn't mind. Just re-schedule the release date. I'm a patient man. But no, instead they decided to scrap the idea and just release the game anyway.Listen Undead Labs, you got a good game here. But unless you bring out a good game that doesn't play like a Facebook game, has challenge but, not at the very beginning and has something that you promised like multiplayer, I can't guarentee you're going to succeed as a video game making company. I'm talking to you as a gamer that knows what's best for the video gaming industry.Thank you and good bye. But please don't let this review take you away from buying this game. If you can handle this game playing it by itself when you're not playing it and if you don't mind it being singleplayer, go ahead at buy this. But I recommend buying it when it's on sale like it is now.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 24, 2014
												What can I say other than the fact that this game is an absolute gem! I waited impatiently for it to come to the PC after reading about it on the 360 - so I jumped at the chance to play it as soon as it came to Early Access (a perfect use of that system too by the way, the game was perfectly playable and only needed a few months to get keyboard support going and to get it properly optimised)Anyway, the game itself is basic but extremely satisfying for the the cost and the fact that is by no means a AAA title. You start out coming back from some hiking trip, there a zombies everywhere, shizzle goes down and you get contacted by some survivors. From there you are pretty much free to raid the towns, camp sites, farms, trailer parks and just about everything else for resoucres to help maintain moral at your base (which you can move around from a church, to houses, a fairground, a warehouse...), make trades with other groups and upgrade your base and make a few helpful trinkets (molotovs, silencers and whatnot)  A minor irritation to me was everyone will speak to you as if you were the same person no matter which survivor you switch to, but it's not that much of a bother as generally you'll build up a preference for one or two of them you'll end up only using anyway! And that's the other thing - you pour time and effort into survivors, build up imaginary details about their lives (They are relativly bland in the ingame story, but give just enough to get a hint of personality in most cases) only to then slip up and be eaten alive - and it's over. Yep, it's perma-death, you're gonna have to find a new favorite because there's no going back when you loose a survivor. And that's it really, the story is decent, may be a little weak if it was AAA but it's not - it's a cheap zombie survival game that most AAA games could only wish to be (I'm looking at you Dead Island!) For the most part graphics are rather nice here on PC, the animations are pretty basic but completly forgivable. The fighting and sneaking mechanics are solid too. It make you fill in most of the story gaps and lets you create your own attachment to the characters as you wish through the threat of losing time and effort put into each person.If you essentially want the closest possible thing to a real "The Walking Dead: The Game" this is it!

content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
												State of Decay is a very good solo zombie-survival simulation. You spend your time building a community of survivors, managing resources, fortifying your hide-out and dealing with the groups interpersonal conflicts. Though it plays more akin to Dead Rising than DayZ the main draw of this game is exploring an immersive open-world, having to trek further and further each day to gather resources, deciding whether to drop your plans at a moments notice because someone on your radio is in trouble. The plot is bare-bones, you make your own emergent stories as you move around the world, having good and bad days, developing an XCom-like attachment to your characters because of the games permadeath system. Get past it's jankier elements in the early-game then it is a compelling experience and a lot of fun. Well worth a try.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												Unlike The Walking Dead, State of Decay’s title doesn’t refer to the zombies or the humans, but refers instead to how your leaderships skills fare against an onslaught of problems. As the executive director of survival resources, morale, zombie extermination, and people’s lives, a lot of weight is placed on your shoulders. Since State of Decay is an open-world persistent simulation that continues when you exit the game, you may find it threatening your real-world responsibilities.My adoration for State of Decay‘s open-world leadership simulation contrasts with my dislike for how much it tempts me away from real responsibilities. But it also draws out why I like leadership simulations where survival is on the line: I love people and want to help them however I can. This also reminds me that if I want to truly be a great leader, I have to be sure to keep my priorities where they truly matter most: on my wife, my work, and my real-world friendships.Read More: http://gamechurch.com/state-of-decay-the-cost-of-caring-leadership/

content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
												With over 900 hours logged on this game, I can honestly say that State of Decay, and it's add-ons, is one of my all-time favorite games.  My wife, who isa casual gamer, kind of fell in love with this game, too.  From the brutal, Savini-esque gore, to the to the heart-breaking decisions of having to put a community member down, this zombie game has just about everything.  A character can climb into a vehicle and plow through a horde of zombies (which will ultimately destroy your vehicle), toss a pipe bomb over the shoulder into a window and clear out a zombie infestation, build structures in your base to aid your community, gather resources, call in artillery fire...for a game that only encompasses about 12 square miles, it is quite epic.  Add on the Breakdown DLC for some sandbox play with ever escalating difficulty levels and loads of heroes to unlock and you've got a LOT of fun.  If you're lucky enough to have the Lifeline DLC, you'll be introduced to a whole new set of characters, with new mission types, and a larger city that isn't Trumball Valley.Pros: Variety of zombie typesUseable vehiclesLarge assortment of melee and ranged weaponsRPG-style elements like leveling up skills, large areas to explore, character backgrounds to discoverExcellent graphics, very usefull 3rd person POVWell-made, moody soundtrack and eerie sound effects, especially in 5.1 surroundModableGamepad friendly (I recommend X-Box 36 controller)Cons:Missions can become repetitive, especially in sandbox (Breakdown) modeSteep system requirements for the highest quality settingsDialog can become monotonous, could use more custom linesWould benefit greatly from co-op, especially local co-op, modeOverall, I highly recommend this game, 4.5/5

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												Not bad when it's on offer; quite simular to Dead Island only third person. You find groups, you build resouces to protect etc as you move through the story.On my version for some reason the graphics were set to low, easily adjustable. Not amazingly designed; you'll notice a few graphical flaws here and there but if you catch the game on offer for around 7.49 then you will get your moneys worth. There isn't much of an introduction upon staring a new game and you are thrown straight into it with a journal to read to gain information on who you are, what you were doing up until the apparant zombie apocalypes.  The controls are pretty simple, nothing strenious i've found. No multiplayer which I found surprising at first but thinking about it; what's the point in paying out for servers when the top dogs are going to be the Left for Dead series and now Dayz for the forseeable future. If Microsoft Studios were realistic about this then possibly a wise move; and a little more investment into the game itself. I think the idea of this is more to game play; the graphics and charactor models themselves are not amazing. In fact if I was being over picky one could say the actual graphics and AI are somewhat terrible. I'd class it as the sensible soccer of zombie games,  it'll never beat the top dogs like fifa (or in this case left for dead and dayz) but does offer a fun alternative.Wait for the sale.

content:

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												State of Decay but as some of my friends would call it, Just every other zombie game. This game however has certain elements to it that are different to any other zombie game I have played. In other games you usually start off with a large group of people with guns and you blast your way through the hordes of zombies that apparantly always know where you are but State of Decay is a different matter all together. Your first weapon is a simple branch you picked up off the ground and you have to use it as best you can to beat some skulls in, the animations for this is very well done and the finishing moves sends the zombies head into the sky. But if your not in the mood to kill or your branch has broken, you can just crouch down, move through the bushes and the zombies won't even know your there which is also good for sneak attacks for an easy kill.I highly recommend this game to anyone who loves survival games or just enjoy the feeling of beating in skulls with a variety of blunt weapons

content:
Posted: May 5, 2014
												First thing about playing State of Decay. DON'T TAKE A LENGTHY BREAK FROM THIS GAME! No. Just don't do it. I'll bring out the spray bottle of water. This game will use resources on each actual day. Not only does this game only have a set amount of resources each playthrough, but your enclave will fraggin' perish if you don't gather them resources after a few days. Only if you have the truck depot or fairgrounds will you be able to gather enough resources for them to last more then a week. And that's if they don't die due to your walls turning to crap.With that out of the way, this is a pretty good zombie sim. You can do distractions, there are special types, the guns feel great, and the artwork is good if it's your style. There is a decent amount of drama, not enough to drown in, and plenty of things to do. As long as, you know, don't run out of resources in your sandbox. That cat poop is useful sometimes.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												Unlike The Walking Dead, State of Decay’s title doesn’t refer to the zombies or the humans, but refers instead to how your leaderships skills fare against an onslaught of problems. As the executive director of survival resources, morale, zombie extermination, and people’s lives, a lot of weight is placed on your shoulders. Since State of Decay is an open-world persistent simulation that continues when you exit the game, you may find it threatening your real-world responsibilities.My adoration for State of Decay‘s open-world leadership simulation contrasts with my dislike for how much it tempts me away from real responsibilities. But it also draws out why I like leadership simulations where survival is on the line: I love people and want to help them however I can. This also reminds me that if I want to truly be a great leader, I have to be sure to keep my priorities where they truly matter most: on my wife, my work, and my real-world friendships.Read More: http://gamechurch.com/state-of-decay-the-cost-of-caring-leadership/

content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												I have played a LOT of this game, it has some very addicting game play features. It is an indie game and was first released on the Xbox 360 as an arcade game, which means they had limited size constraints in building the game. This, however, did not stop them from making a very fun zombie apocalypse game where the goal is keeping your group together and alive. This is NOT a 'go kill zombie, atta boy' game, there is so much more to it than that.1. You do not play as one character. Everybody whom you have 'friended' in your base, you can play. 2. If your character dies, you automatically switch to another friend in your base and continue play.3. You can level up your active character by doing things that would logically enhance those abilities. Run a lot to build up your stamina. Battle zombies to gain combat skills. Shoot zombies to gain firing skills. Ect...4. There are a lot of guns to choose from in the game, over 100. There are a lot of melee weapons, but not quite the plethoria as the guns.5. Noise. Keep it quiet if you don't want zombies breathing down your neck. Feeling good about yourself, make some noise and take out the incoming zombies!6. Vehicles, take them for a spin. Unlike other games like FarCry, where the vehicles seem to have one center wheel, the vehicles in this game act just like real vehicles should, with 4 tires on the ground. It has been noted, however, that you sometimes get launched into space, or hit invisible obstacles. I only saw this when I had a slow computer, so if thats you, be prepared for it. You can also stash loot in the trunks for your scavanging pleasure! I especially like driving by zombies and take them out with the car door! Ha ha!7. The map is static, but the containers that might have loot, and the loot itself is random, every time you play the game. Its a good sized map. And you can enter 96% of the buildings on the map looking for loot to bring back to base.8. You can bring one follower along with you, from your base. There are other survivors out there looking for a safe place to stay, will you gain their trust enough so that they want to join you? Do those people have useful skills that you could use at your base?9. Your base. There are several locations across the map where you can setup your base. Each one has different requirements and has a different set of built in facilities, as well as open facility slots you can build on. Do you want the medical facility, or perhaps the kitchen. But then, the gym would help increase your stamina. Oh, the watchtower can be used to shoot zombies that get too close. But, a workshop could repair your weapons and your vehicles. Or a machine shop so you can build pipe bombs... So many things to choose from and you only have a limites number of spots.10. Missions? Lots of them from story missions to base moral missions, to helping other survivors in order to gain their trust. The game is frantic at times, with zombie hoards heading to your base that you have to take out before they arrive, to survivors in dire need of immediate aide!And there is so much more in this game. For the price, this game has a great deal going for it and will keep you busy for a long time. Its also very enjoyable and I think anyone who likes an open world, some base building features along with exploration and scavenging will also enjoy this game.

content:
Posted: November 12, 2013
												This game is definately one of the best zombie-based survival games I've played. Along with your standard goal of not dying, Stated of Decay goes further by implementing emotion and character attachment. Two of the main protagonists are brother and sister, and if you let something happen to either one of them, the other will chew your♥♥♥♥♥up and generally just make you feel like a total ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.I also love the immersion in this game (though currently it still needs some polishing). Zombies here are a THREAT. Not just something that you kill help level up your character, but a huge_♥♥♥♥ing_threat. I don't think I've ever faced more than 4 zombies at once without getting some major and sometimes irrecoverable scars.Guns, the most sought-after thing in any zombie game save for the first Dead Island (where they were so weak and ammo was so scarce that they pretty much weren't worth it). In State of Decay, if you shoot as much as a .22 cal round without a suppressor, a horde of at least half a dozen zombies (read: 4 zombies gave me near-fatal wounds, your irresponsible shot will attract a minimum of 6). Ammo is also very scarce and valuable. You better make damn sure that every shot you make, silenced or not, is a headshot or at least enough to stun the zombie you shot at. Currently I haven't tried automatic guns such as the LMG and SMG (yes this game has a light machine gun), but I know for damn sure that I'm never gonna shoot anything with them without backup.Scavenging. The heart and soul of survival games. Without scavenging you have a mediocre shoot-em-up game. State of Decay makes scavenging very important with the use of random occurences where some food might go bad, a wall might crack, or someone getting critically ill. It's also sometimes dangerous to scavenge alone or in an infected area, and I can say that it's pretty damn nerve-racking when a zombie comes out of nowhere and bites the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of you.In State of Decay, you will have the opportunity to kill off members of your survival group. Sometimes it's a show of mercy, like if they've become infected (note: bites from zombies do not infect you), or they're so sick that they can't recover. Sometimes it's out of spite, like if the survivor facing death contaminated food supplies, or killed another survivor. And sometimes you can kill someone for generally just being an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.Finaly, let's talk about character skills. You can control several different characters in State of Decay, and they each level up differently according to how you play as them. You can max out general shooting and rifle skills to get them near-military level marksman training, or max out their fighting skills to let them smash every zombie head they see. You can max out their cardio ("#1: if you run out of stamina, that's it. Can't fight, can't run away, you're done." - description of Cardio skill) to let them endure longer fights and still have the stamina to run away.Overall, State of Decay is amazing, and currently seems to be underrated.10/10 zombie heads.--Note--This game progresses even when you leave the game, so if you leave your party with low morale and supplies, when you get back♥♥♥♥♥♥is gonna hit the fan.--Note2--This game does not have multiplayer, and it is uncertain if the developers will eventually implement it.

												One of the best zombie survival games I've played.Managing the resources at your base, scavenging for those resources, vehicles.The things I don't like about it however is I wish there an easier way to ramp the difficulty up earlier on.(No difficulty options in Vanilla, on Breakdown you need to unlock difficulty levels by completing them.)I also wish there were more map selections and/or random maps.The default map is a decent size though, so i'm not overly picky about it, but it can get old after awhile.And also there's no multiplayer, though I've heard it might be added, that would definitely be a huge plus.Despite those negatives, anyone interesting in a good zombie survival game should definitely pick it up;I hesitated due to negative reviews and that was a big mistake, I'm very happy I picked it up.

content:
Posted: December 9, 2013
												This is the best zombie apocalypse game I could ever dream of. I am f*cking serious. Seems like developers took all the best from lots of games and made an ultimate zombie survival sandbox. This game reminds me so much of GTA, Left 4 Dead, The Walking Dead, Dead Rising and even the old Jagged Alliance (probably because of team management and it's color spectrum lol)- open world (area is not that big, but you can enter and scavenge any place or building you want);- tons of weapons ranged from melee (from baseball bats and shovels to wakizashi and braid) to heavy guns and grenade launchers etc.;- tons of different combat skills and perks, which really bring diversity into a simple fight;- random character generation (apart from plot characters);- character leveling;- plot missions which lead you through the game but are not annoying and you can play them whenever you want (I've played nearly 30 hours until I decided to get through the story);- base and team management, building of different facilities for survivors, upgrading them;- great soundtrack (COUNTRY ♥♥♥♥ YEAH) and ambient which makes already thick atmosphere even stronger;And of course, dat feel when you slam passing by zombies with your car's side door – OMG 10 out of 10 GOTYP.S. I didn’t expect this game to be so cool when I first heard of it. Some say (especially the ones who haven’t played it or played on youtube) that it is too casual, arcade and console-like, but it’s not true. This game has great atmosphere which overcomes everything. Seriously, just give it a try. Yes, graphics is not that good, but it is not that important. Plus, the developers have fixed lots of bugs and problems with controls, thank God I didn’t play this game during the early access, it would kill the first impression for sure.P.P.S. This game does not need multiplayer or co-op of any kind. It would kill all the atmosphere.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												Not bad when it's on offer; quite simular to Dead Island only third person. You find groups, you build resouces to protect etc as you move through the story.On my version for some reason the graphics were set to low, easily adjustable. Not amazingly designed; you'll notice a few graphical flaws here and there but if you catch the game on offer for around 7.49 then you will get your moneys worth. There isn't much of an introduction upon staring a new game and you are thrown straight into it with a journal to read to gain information on who you are, what you were doing up until the apparant zombie apocalypes.  The controls are pretty simple, nothing strenious i've found. No multiplayer which I found surprising at first but thinking about it; what's the point in paying out for servers when the top dogs are going to be the Left for Dead series and now Dayz for the forseeable future. If Microsoft Studios were realistic about this then possibly a wise move; and a little more investment into the game itself. I think the idea of this is more to game play; the graphics and charactor models themselves are not amazing. In fact if I was being over picky one could say the actual graphics and AI are somewhat terrible. I'd class it as the sensible soccer of zombie games,  it'll never beat the top dogs like fifa (or in this case left for dead and dayz) but does offer a fun alternative.Wait for the sale.

Posted: March 15, 2015
												One word. Actual survival. This isn't a standard "Left for dead" or even "Dead Island." you have to upkeep your home base as well as expanding. You can take over other areas. You have to keep your team's morale up. It actually has guns that you can get ammo for! Dead Island was a great game except the fact that there was no ammo. You found guns but never wanted to use them because all you have is 6 shots in the entire game. This game you have to manage resources as well. I have not played "Dying Light" because my computer cannot run it but this game beats all of other zombie survival games out there. I 500% recommend this. It is a great value for the price.

content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
												With over 900 hours logged on this game, I can honestly say that State of Decay, and it's add-ons, is one of my all-time favorite games.  My wife, who isa casual gamer, kind of fell in love with this game, too.  From the brutal, Savini-esque gore, to the to the heart-breaking decisions of having to put a community member down, this zombie game has just about everything.  A character can climb into a vehicle and plow through a horde of zombies (which will ultimately destroy your vehicle), toss a pipe bomb over the shoulder into a window and clear out a zombie infestation, build structures in your base to aid your community, gather resources, call in artillery fire...for a game that only encompasses about 12 square miles, it is quite epic.  Add on the Breakdown DLC for some sandbox play with ever escalating difficulty levels and loads of heroes to unlock and you've got a LOT of fun.  If you're lucky enough to have the Lifeline DLC, you'll be introduced to a whole new set of characters, with new mission types, and a larger city that isn't Trumball Valley.Pros: Variety of zombie typesUseable vehiclesLarge assortment of melee and ranged weaponsRPG-style elements like leveling up skills, large areas to explore, character backgrounds to discoverExcellent graphics, very usefull 3rd person POVWell-made, moody soundtrack and eerie sound effects, especially in 5.1 surroundModableGamepad friendly (I recommend X-Box 36 controller)Cons:Missions can become repetitive, especially in sandbox (Breakdown) modeSteep system requirements for the highest quality settingsDialog can become monotonous, could use more custom linesWould benefit greatly from co-op, especially local co-op, modeOverall, I highly recommend this game, 4.5/5

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
												State of Decay is a very good solo zombie-survival simulation. You spend your time building a community of survivors, managing resources, fortifying your hide-out and dealing with the groups interpersonal conflicts. Though it plays more akin to Dead Rising than DayZ the main draw of this game is exploring an immersive open-world, having to trek further and further each day to gather resources, deciding whether to drop your plans at a moments notice because someone on your radio is in trouble. The plot is bare-bones, you make your own emergent stories as you move around the world, having good and bad days, developing an XCom-like attachment to your characters because of the games permadeath system. Get past it's jankier elements in the early-game then it is a compelling experience and a lot of fun. Well worth a try.

content:
Posted: February 2, 2015
												Probably one of the best Zombie games put out in the last few years.The best way to describe this really is It's San Andreas with zombies, an easy, lesser focus on maintaing your base/resource management and some decent writing. Just don't expect TellTale's The Walking Dead here, as while it's not a game with a tongue in cheek tone, it's not exactly the most serious game in town. Think Dead Island at face value but a tad more serious. It's a bit of a rough game, it's not exactly the prettiest looking, the controls may feel a little wonky at first, but if you're up for a game about scavenging through areas infested with zombies, dealing with problems within your group, and every once and a while having some emergent moments like watching in horror as a runner gets litterally torn in half captain rhodes day of the dead style in the middle of the street after getting surrounded and downed by a horde. The melee combat is a bit like a stripped down superpower-less Arkham Asylum that makes fighting hordes feel just as difficult and tiring as it reasonably should. While guns are by nature as much of a liability as they are a reward, the gunplay's fine, it's just that the crosshair is a bit too large to be reliable on higher resolutions for which i'd REALLY reccomend the Widescreen Crosshair Fix mod found here: http://www.nexusmods.com/stateofdecay/mods/15/? . Cars are similarily very useful and a bit of a risk, although they are the best way to get around the map, the game does throw some roadblocks every once and a while on roads to make driving a bit more difficult, although you can use mods to remove those if they annoy you.There are a few mechanics that might "tick you off" a bit if you have seething hatred for them and so I'll list them below:-Character Permadeath, if a character dies/Goes down three times, they're dead. No getting them back. Even story relevant characters can die but it will never make the game unbeatable.-A persistent World aspect a bit like Animal Crossing although don't worry, you won't not play for a week to find everything in shambles. The longer you're not playing, the slower time moves and if I recall it caps at 3 hours. -A level of repetition very late into the game, and light annoyance at times. I've seen the game be criticized for this, but at some point parts of the tasks might start to feel a bit repetitive, but this is mostly stuff related to scavenging necessary items and helping characters through emotional states. The annoyance part I mentioned relates to stuff like having to deal with stuff rather constantly, there will very rarely be a moment that something won't need to be done for someone or around the safehouse. Someone might need saving(Outposts reduce the chances of this happening, increasing the area zombies won't spawn in.), someone might need help with their anxiety (Which always results in you killing zombies with them. It's a bit lazy and repetitive but with the amount of♥♥♥♥♥♥in this game already I can forgive it.), there's story missions to do all while you're trying to keep the safehouse running, everyone healthy and also trying to make towards your next goal and trying not to screw yourself further down the line.The story itself is nothing special really, but it is written competently and while not every character feels like more than just an NPC, it does it's job fleshing most of them out. I can't think of a main character I could really call "bland and lifeless".One last thing, but this game isn't amazingly well optimized for lower end systems. You should be fine if you have a moderate or high end rig, but if your computer lands more on the "toaster" end, you probably won't be able to tweak the settings too heavily to save your performance. Honstly, if something irks you about the game, look through the mods there's probably going to be something there to fix it. If you like zombie games just about at all, or what I described interests you, grab this game.

content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												Lets start this off by saying this game is one of those surprises, My first time playing it I will be honest I hated it. The gameplay was just not for me, but the more time I have spent with this game the more I am loving it. Its like that annoying friend that you love yet want to strangle at the same time, What I mean by that is the survial aspect of this game is wonderful. And the gameplay ended up opening up past what I saw in my first play through. While other zombie games focus more on the killing or maybe the looting this game focuses on a group dynamic. It will make you consider putting your character in danger in order to bring back supplies for a sick group member, or maybe searching a market for more food to feed the group, buy doing so putting yourself at risk to being torn apart and having your character being gone for good. Yes there is perma death meaning if you level up a character and make one mistake they are gone forever all that time you invested in them gone in a blink of an eye. It really changes your mentality on how you go about day to day things in this game, Not only are you wanting to put yourself at risk to better your group but by doing so you risk your own character and these struggles really start getting to you. You can of course ease the struggle buy leveling your character, traveling with a partner which will cost influnce or calling in favors like back up from a swat team or you can set up outpost to protect them more allowing them a better chance at survial on supply runs they will make.This game does have some glitches and bugs let me be clear I am by no means gonna say it doesnt this is not a perfect game by the hardware standpoint but for me none of them are game breaking or really upset me annoying yes and that is what I ment by that friend you want to strangle, but by no means are they bad enough for me to rage out and want to never play again. Not once did a bug hinder my ability to play the game or did it effect a mission for me up to this point.This game is a wonderful refreshing take on zombie survial and at the end of the day that is what this game is and survial game where you try your best to hold out as long as possible with what you can scavenge or with the people you meet its not all that spectacular in the terms of story but at the heart of it you have a real to earth hardcore zombie survial game and that is all it claims to be and it delivers with great gameplay and new take on the genre that I really enjoyed.

												STATE OF DECAY-------------------------------Story line:It is a little bit confusing, as you start a new game you immediatly land into a situation where you have to act fast to save your friend. content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												This is one of my all time favorite games that you will commonly see me playing and talking about with my friends, Its a great game that has provided hours of fun for me and friends. Now, i could talk ya ear off but i wont, heres the review ↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓Postitive+Extremely addicting zombie game +Character progression is pretty balanced (You can farm, but by just playing the game to can get all you skills to max easily)+Nice story+Wide array of weapons, from a simple 2x4 to a 50. cal rifle with an underbarrel grenade launcher (Funny thing is im not even kidding)+Skills in the game are amazing, I chopped 3 zombie's legs off all in one slice+Your character isnt some unfit fat person, (Even the fat people can) they can climb fences, hop barricades, drop kick zombies, roll around, hell, you can even slow down time!+The base game brings alot of fun and can be replayed multiple times without losing the sense of fun!+The DLCs add even more fun, from stranded survivors trying to escape the valley to a heroic squad of soldiers trying to find a cure+The community building aspect, You can slowly build up a beastly community that cant be brought down, or have most of your community wiped out by the Black Fever+Special Zombies, They can add a bit of a challenge, like the Feral, or be a complete annoyance, Im lookin' at you screamer!+Perma-death, Although ive lost multiple max characters to this, it adds more realism to the game+Companions actually help, They can grab zombies and let you 1-shot them mid combat,+I could go on about the smaller aspects of the game and waste a couple more hours of my life talking about this great game, but for now, here are some NegativesNegative (Not many actually .-.)-Kick off (Basicly its when a bunch of survivors have trapped a zombie in a corner and constantly kick it, even when they have a weapon, Still quite fun to watch ^-^ )-No MP (SoD2 is going to have it! The gods have anwsered our prayers!)-Control Glitches (Only encountered a couple)-Sleep & Fatigue needs work-Arent really any hostile survivors (Closest ive come is 2 dudes demanding ammo from another guy)

content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												I have played a LOT of this game, it has some very addicting game play features. It is an indie game and was first released on the Xbox 360 as an arcade game, which means they had limited size constraints in building the game. This, however, did not stop them from making a very fun zombie apocalypse game where the goal is keeping your group together and alive. This is NOT a 'go kill zombie, atta boy' game, there is so much more to it than that.1. You do not play as one character. Everybody whom you have 'friended' in your base, you can play. 2. If your character dies, you automatically switch to another friend in your base and continue play.3. You can level up your active character by doing things that would logically enhance those abilities. Run a lot to build up your stamina. Battle zombies to gain combat skills. Shoot zombies to gain firing skills. Ect...4. There are a lot of guns to choose from in the game, over 100. There are a lot of melee weapons, but not quite the plethoria as the guns.5. Noise. Keep it quiet if you don't want zombies breathing down your neck. Feeling good about yourself, make some noise and take out the incoming zombies!6. Vehicles, take them for a spin. Unlike other games like FarCry, where the vehicles seem to have one center wheel, the vehicles in this game act just like real vehicles should, with 4 tires on the ground. It has been noted, however, that you sometimes get launched into space, or hit invisible obstacles. I only saw this when I had a slow computer, so if thats you, be prepared for it. You can also stash loot in the trunks for your scavanging pleasure! I especially like driving by zombies and take them out with the car door! Ha ha!7. The map is static, but the containers that might have loot, and the loot itself is random, every time you play the game. Its a good sized map. And you can enter 96% of the buildings on the map looking for loot to bring back to base.8. You can bring one follower along with you, from your base. There are other survivors out there looking for a safe place to stay, will you gain their trust enough so that they want to join you? Do those people have useful skills that you could use at your base?9. Your base. There are several locations across the map where you can setup your base. Each one has different requirements and has a different set of built in facilities, as well as open facility slots you can build on. Do you want the medical facility, or perhaps the kitchen. But then, the gym would help increase your stamina. Oh, the watchtower can be used to shoot zombies that get too close. But, a workshop could repair your weapons and your vehicles. Or a machine shop so you can build pipe bombs... So many things to choose from and you only have a limites number of spots.10. Missions? Lots of them from story missions to base moral missions, to helping other survivors in order to gain their trust. The game is frantic at times, with zombie hoards heading to your base that you have to take out before they arrive, to survivors in dire need of immediate aide!And there is so much more in this game. For the price, this game has a great deal going for it and will keep you busy for a long time. Its also very enjoyable and I think anyone who likes an open world, some base building features along with exploration and scavenging will also enjoy this game.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												Finally a zombie game that actually gets the point of zombies! It's not about shooting zombies - they're slow and stupid! No, it's all about the base - you know I'm right. You and your friends already know where your base is going to be if a Zombie Apocalypse happens - you've planned it in detail, worked out who you'd take, what to loot first.Yet Zombie games are all about wandering around on your own, shooting them. Until now. State of Decay places you in the midst of the Zombie Apocalypse and your onjective is primal - survive, by pulling together a team of other survivors with the skills you need, finding and modifying a base to fill your needs and keeping it supplied. To make this somewhat more difficult, you have zombies trying to eat you. You have your basic Ready Salted Zombie, slow, stupid, endlessly hungry and more than a little squishy, especially around the head. But just to make things a little more tricky, you have a cavalcade of Freaks - mutant zombies with different patterns of behaviour to normal. And they are NASTY.In any game about survival, it's important that however skilled you become, there is something that can kill you unless it screws up or you don't, and State of Decay provides these in a plethora of different ways. Zombies are attracted to noise, so fire your gun without a silencer, crash your car or have a companion who dies screaming and they will start homing in on you from miles away. The more zombies you're fighting, the louder things get and the more zombies come. The endless numbers can wear you down and as exhaustion takes its toll, the end is often close behind.If not through a steady trickle of reinforcements, you might instead fall afoul of a full-fledged zombie horde, wandering the streets looking for warm-blooded food. Your location might be surrounded by them and fall under siege and yes, you do get to board up the windows. It keeps you safe for a while, until some gigantic redneck farmchild too large to fit through the door punches it through, drags you out and tears you in two. Flee and you might be run down by a speeding deceased member of the armed forces or a SWAT team agent in full body-armour and helmet, or pounced on from out of the blue by the swift and deadly animalistic Ferals.Successfully combine your fighting and running and get clear and back to base? Don't worry, you'll probably still die from the Black Fever carried by bloated, ancient corpses in the mob - and by your companions, once they're exposed. Medicine is in short supply and medical know-how, even shorter - you either recover, or you die... and then come back for your friends.If all that's not enough, you have the armed forces up to dubious things in the area, a former judge attempting to enforce the rules of civilized society in a world where there isn't one, a redneck family one banjo short of Deliverance, a doomed love affair and a passel of mis-matched survivors steadily driving each other insane. Suicide, murder and run-aways are all risks you'll run, along with drug addiction from the amphetamines you're jamming down your throat and up your nose just to stay on your feet. Oh, and one of you might just be a serial killer. State of Decay gives a proper nod to all the tropes of the genre. I haven't found any chainsaws, which seems a grotesque oversight, but you can spot the zombies who've been chewed through the chest by a lawnmower a la "Braindead". Look closely enough at the magazine racks and grocery packaging and see the order to OBEY from "They Live", Hedge trimmers? Check. Oar? Yup. The faithful rusty pipe of Silent Hill? Aw hells, yeah. Can you knock a Zed's head off by opening the car door as you drive past it at speed? Of course!The base locations are also classics - a shipping warehouse, a posh walled manor, the local Church, a barricaded farmhouse out of town, an amusement park... all have their pros and cons and on the whole, are very well-balanced.The main weak point of the game is characterization, with little more than a few lines of insight into one motivation of some of the characters, which appears in a dialogue when the character is getting to know you. In a game where you're expected to lose a few characters and switch to playing others, a measure of emotional attachment would really add to the atmosphere. Game mechanics, however, provide a surrogate reason to get attached to characters - after all that time training their skills, the loss of a character can bring a chilling feeling of doom, especially if they were the only one in your band of survivors with an essential skill, and the moods of your fellow survivors crash drastically after any loss.While vanilla State of Decay's story mode is great fun, where it really comes into its own is with the Breakdown DLC. Breakdown sets the game to sandbox mode. You start with only your character (and Lily, your non-combatant radio operator) and build up a group and a base, accomplish certain objectives to unlock new characters or recruit other groups of survivors, play the level for as long as you wish, however you wish, then pick your six favourite characters, bundle them onto an RV with all your remaining gear and start the level again... only this time it's harder. And then you do it again, and again, and again. Your characters can become pretty experienced like this, but only if they survive. The ratio of difficulty to character skill is very well judged, so no matter how well you survived the last x levels and how godly your characters are, there is always a definite sense that you are in much more trouble this time... without it ever quite feeling impossible.The game has a few bugs, but they are mostly minor and don't crop up repeatedly, so they're not game breaking but you might lose a character or two to teleporting Freaks or your car suddenly flipping and exploding for no reason.If you're looking for a Zombie Apocalypse simulator, this is the one you've been waiting for while you plot your survival strategies in the pub with friends. Don't forget to buy Breakdown, because the story mode will have you aching for the sandbox during those moments when the plot is demanding your attention and you want to ransack just one... more.. cupboard.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
												A single player game where you are a community of survivors trying not to die in a recent zombie apocalypse.Realtime Third person action/foraging game.SummaryI love the game but it has its flaws, well worth the price.The DrawPermenant character death (the gear/backpack is recoverable from a dead survivor) and you control an individual but can call out backup from home or other survivor communities in a fight or to cart the heavy cargo home (optional escort quest or let them solo the risk).Vehicles with decent variation (from sensible 4 door family wagons to 4 x 4 pickups and 2 door musclecars)suprisingly threatening zombies. The standard zombies are dangerous in packs, special infected need specific takedown methods (bullet immune, boomer, tank/charger hybrid, stalker), which can encourage you to take the risk and bring a friendly NPC with you (unless its the tank hunt mission in which case it is certain death to the somewhat sluggish NPC character)good map setup where after the campaign intro you can move to and fortify one of several base site options, the dlc provides an endless map escalation scenario (campaign map with an escape to make harder function), and a mode focussed on base defence and deep insertion rescue and harvesting missions.moving around is kept dangerous, campaign map resources are finite so each reload full of (noisy) bullets is important, damaged mele weapons need to be swapped out for fresh ones before they break so they can be repaired overnight, cars though numerous and powerful can start to become limited later on if you crash to many times or get caught offguard while mowing down a horde.the detrimentI had an issue with the storage box where it would force me ot take the 1st item selected whenever I opened the crate, gear is requisitioned by faction/fame points and taking an item out costa more than putting an item in. the bug lead to rare shortages of fame (when it pulled out a ranged weapon)The combat is functional but clunky, the special moves/passives earned by capping player traits help but the basic mele and gun combat lacks depth. distractions, firebombs, grenades, etc help but Lack of sneak options. Later on with a capable/levelled survivor I could manage a horde or 2 horde with manageable risk and careful use of a moltov, there were few opportunities where stealth felt like an option. quietly foraging a house in the middle of an infected area is one thing but every new house seemed to have 3-5 zombies you had to take out in the process, being quiet only prevents a roaming herd from getting in on the action (which tends to waste a sizeable portion of resouces to handle safely)core gameplay is similar to dead island, assassins creed (fixed world, unimaginative mele and satisfying stealth kills) and system shock 2 (there's you and an environment and the aggressive hordes out for your blood, resources are limited and you need to get stuff done)

content:
Posted: October 27, 2013
												Probably one of the best zombie type games I have played in a long time. Picture GTA with zombies but with more complex gameplay. Build up your homesite the way you want. Make sure you have a medical area and enough beds for everyone to sleep. Create a workshop for crafting and repairing. Upgrade it and find a mechanic survivor and he/she can work on cars for you. Want to turn your canned goods into a feast make sure you have a chef survivor. When this place gets too small move to another area with a bigger site to call home. Missions go on even while you are not playing.. your other survivors are always active. The current state of the beta is still very much playable. A little buggy at some points but there is no reason you cant fully enjoy it. Oh and I just found out that while you are playing as X survivor they do have the ability to die but the game goes on. You can switch and play as any of the survivors that have a high enough firend/trust relationship with you.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												State of Decay is the stand-out game of the Summer Sale so far.  It is an open world zombie game that does a lot of things right. In each expansion you control a community who is trying to survive the zombie apocalypse.  You are collecting supplies, upgrading your home, and trying to stay alive.  You control one character at a time but can switch freely between the other members of your community.  Easily worth the price of the Steam Sale.  The expansions are stand-alone scenarios so if you are wary about buying the game then you can just start with the base.  The only negative points I'd give it are for technical issues.  I was crashing semi-frequently but I was able to sort the issues out and hasn't happened much since.

												Great zombie survival game. I love how you can grow your survivor community and fortify your areas. When I first bought this game I played it non-stop through the story and then bought the expansion and have since kind of stopped playing as much. It's a good simple game that you can pick up where you left off and play off and on as you wish.All in all I think SoD is worth $20. I just hope to see better expansions in the future. The current expansion, SoD- Breakdown, is just more of the same original game. Same locations, safehouses and zombies. Not worth the money.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
												State of Decay is a very good solo zombie-survival simulation. You spend your time building a community of survivors, managing resources, fortifying your hide-out and dealing with the groups interpersonal conflicts. Though it plays more akin to Dead Rising than DayZ the main draw of this game is exploring an immersive open-world, having to trek further and further each day to gather resources, deciding whether to drop your plans at a moments notice because someone on your radio is in trouble. The plot is bare-bones, you make your own emergent stories as you move around the world, having good and bad days, developing an XCom-like attachment to your characters because of the games permadeath system. Get past it's jankier elements in the early-game then it is a compelling experience and a lot of fun. Well worth a try.
